Massachusetts General Laws c. 186, \u00a.proposition: This action is brought pursuant to **Massachusetts General Laws c. 186, § 14**, which provides a private cause of action for tenants whose landlords interfere with the tenant’s quiet enjoyment of leased premises.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7 2.proposition: Venue is proper in the **Lowell District Court** under **G.L. c. 223, § 2** because the events giving rise to this complaint occurred within the judicial district of Lowell.

105 C.M.R. 410.000 et seq..proposition: The Premises is a residential dwelling unit subject to **Massachusetts General Laws c. 186, § 14** and the **State Sanitary Code**, **105 C.M.R. 410.000 et seq.**

105 C.M.R. 410.602, 410.500, 410.750.proposition: The continuing mold condition violates the **State Sanitary Code** (105 C.M.R. 410.602, 410.500, 410.750) and thus constitutes interference with the quiet enjoyment of the premises (*McKenna v. Begin*, 3 Mass. App. Ct. 168 [1975]*; *Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91 [1982]*).

G.L. c. 239, \u00a7 8A (Defenses and cou.raw_text: G.L. c. 239, § 8A (Defenses and counterclaims related to uninhabitable premises)
G.L. c. 239, \u00a7 8A (Defenses and cou.proposition: G.L. c. 239, § 8A (Defenses and counterclaims related to uninhabitable premises)

*Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway*, 363.proposition: Defendant’s conduct has also breached the **implied warranty of habitability** (*Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway*, 363 Mass. 184 [1973]) and the **State Sanitary Code** (*Crowell v. McCaffrey*, 377 Mass. 443 [1979]).
*Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway*, 363.support_reasoning: This excerpt is from Justice Quirico’s concurrence/dissent, which explicitly disagrees with the majority’s broader formulation of an implied warranty of habitability and argues instead for a narrower duty tied to compliance with the State Sanitary Code. The proposition cited uses Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway as affirmative authority that the defendant’s conduct breached an implied warranty of habitability and the Code; while the majority opinion in Hemingway does recognize such an implied warranty, this particular text does not itself establish or affirm that rule and in fact criticizes the majority’s approach. Thus, this opinion segment does not support the proposition for which it is cited.
*Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway*, 363.relevant_excerpt: “The point at which I dissent from the opinion of the court is where it attempts to accomplish the first step by resort to an implied warranty of the fitness of the rented dwelling unit instead of by the implication of an agreement that the unit will comply with the minimum standards required therefor by law.… The court makes no attempt to define what is required to make a dwelling unit ‘fit for human occupation’… I dissent from the statement of such a broad and sweeping new rule…”

*Crowell v. McCaffrey*, 377 Mass. 443 [1.proposition: Defendant’s conduct has also breached the **implied warranty of habitability** (*Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway*, 363 Mass. 184 [1973]) and the **State Sanitary Code** (*Crowell v. McCaffrey*, 377 Mass. 443 [1979]).
*Crowell v. McCaffrey*, 377 Mass. 443 [1.support_reasoning: Crowell does address an implied warranty arising from compliance with the State Building and Sanitary Codes, but it is careful to *avoid* deciding the broader scope of the Hemingway ‘warranty of habitability.’ The court expressly limits its holding to an implied agreement that the rented unit complies with minimum code standards, and says it does “not consider the scope of the broader warranty of habitability.” Thus Crowell supports a code‑compliance warranty, not the full Hemingway habitability warranty, and cannot accurately be cited as authority that defendant’s conduct breached the implied warranty of habitability itself.
*Crowell v. McCaffrey*, 377 Mass. 443 [1.relevant_excerpt: “For present purposes we need not go beyond the more limited rule. We therefore do not consider the scope of the broader warranty of habitability, or the extent to which the porch in the present case was a ‘vital’ facility. We now find in the rental of a dwelling unit…an implied agreement by the landlord that the rented unit complies with the minimum standards prescribed by building and sanitary codes and that he will do whatever those codes require for compliance during the term of the renting.”

*Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. 714 [19.proposition: **Massachusetts law** recognizes that a landlord’s failure to correct unsafe or unsanitary conditions can constitute interference under this statute (*Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. 714 [1977]; *Haddad v. Gonzalez*, 410 Mass. 855 [1991]*; *Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847 [1997]*).
*Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. 714 [19.support_reasoning: Blackett concerns constructive eviction and breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment based on excessive noise from a lounge the landlord introduced and could control; it does not involve or discuss unsafe or unsanitary conditions. The court’s analysis focuses on noise/disturbance as interference with quiet enjoyment and the landlord’s control over that condition, not on health or sanitation issues. Thus, while it supports the broader idea that landlord failure to correct certain conditions can constitute interference, it does not specifically support the proposition as phrased about unsafe or unsanitary conditions under Massachusetts law.
*Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. 714 [19.relevant_excerpt: “There are occasions, however, where a landlord has not intended to violate a tenant’s rights, but there was nevertheless a breach of the landlord’s covenant of quiet enjoyment which flowed as the natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, what he failed to do, or what he permitted to be done… Because the disturbing condition was the natural and probable consequence of the landlords’ permitting the lounge to operate where it did and because the landlords could control the actions at the lounge, they should not be entitled to collect rent for residential premises which were not reasonably habitable.”

*Haddad v. Gonzalez*, 410 Mass. 855 [199.proposition: **Massachusetts law** recognizes that a landlord’s failure to correct unsafe or unsanitary conditions can constitute interference under this statute (*Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. 714 [1977]; *Haddad v. Gonzalez*, 410 Mass. 855 [1991]*; *Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847 [1997]*).
*Haddad v. Gonzalez*, 410 Mass. 855 [199.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses breach of the implied warranty of habitability, the covenant of quiet enjoyment, retaliation, and especially c. 93A emotional-distress damages, but it does not analyze what constitutes ‘interference’ under G.L. c. 186, § 14, nor does it state that a landlord’s failure to correct unsafe or unsanitary conditions alone constitutes interference for that statute. Any quiet-enjoyment violation is mentioned only in passing as one of several counterclaims and not as a basis for a legal rule about interference. Thus, Haddad v. Gonzalez does not provide doctrinal support for the specific proposition claimed.
*Haddad v. Gonzalez*, 410 Mass. 855 [199.relevant_excerpt: After her landlord, the plaintiff Nick Haddad, commenced a summary process action in the Housing Court for the city of Boston for nonpayment of rent, the defendant, Luz Gonzalez, filed six counterclaims alleging: (1) breach of the implied warranty of habitability; (2) breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment in violation of G.L.c. 186, § 14 (1990 ed.); (3) negligent failure to maintain the premises; (4) intentional infliction of emotional distress; (5) retaliation in violation of G.L.c. 186, § 18; and (6) violations of G.L.c. 93A. After a trial, a judge of the Housing Court found in favor of Gonzalez on all of her counterclaims... We now affirm.

*Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847 [199.proposition: **Massachusetts law** recognizes that a landlord’s failure to correct unsafe or unsanitary conditions can constitute interference under this statute (*Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. 714 [1977]; *Haddad v. Gonzalez*, 410 Mass. 855 [1991]*; *Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847 [1997]*).
*Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847 [199.support_reasoning: The case directly addresses G.L. c. 186, § 14 and clarifies that a landlord can violate the covenant of quiet enjoyment by negligently failing to correct hazardous conditions of which the landlord has notice or reason to know. In explaining the required "some degree of fault," the Court explicitly identifies a landlord’s failure to repair known defects—unsafe or uninhabitable conditions—as conduct that has been deemed a § 14 violation. Thus, it affirms that failure to correct unsafe or unsanitary conditions can constitute interference under the statute, consistent with Blackett and Haddad.
*Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847 [199.relevant_excerpt: We noted that a landlord’s failure “to repair defects of which he has notice in leased premises is an omission which frequently has been deemed to violate § 14.” See Cruz, supra at 789, citing Simon v. Solomon, supra at 103 (failure to control floods in tenant’s apartment); Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass. 758, 761 (1979) (failure to repair leaky roof); Dorgan v. Loukas, 19 Mass. App. Ct. 959, 960 (1985) (failure to bring apartment into habitable condition and keep it so). Today we make clear what was implicit in those rulings: to support the imposition of liability under the quiet enjoyment statute, there must be a showing of at least negligent conduct by a landlord….

*McKenna v. Begin*, 3 Mass. App. Ct. 168.proposition: The continuing mold condition violates the **State Sanitary Code** (105 C.M.R. 410.602, 410.500, 410.750) and thus constitutes interference with the quiet enjoyment of the premises (*McKenna v. Begin*, 3 Mass. App. Ct. 168 [1975]*; *Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91 [1982]*).
*McKenna v. Begin*, 3 Mass. App. Ct. 168.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses the implied warranty of habitability and its relationship to the State Sanitary Code in general, but it does not address mold, the specific cited regulatory sections (105 C.M.R. 410.602, 410.500, 410.750), or explicitly link a particular Sanitary Code violation to interference with quiet enjoyment. Its holding concerns the measure and period of damages for breach of the implied warranty, not that a continuing mold condition violates the Code and thereby constitutes interference with quiet enjoyment. Thus it is too general to support the specific proposition claimed.
*McKenna v. Begin*, 3 Mass. App. Ct. 168.relevant_excerpt: “There the court stated, ‘[W]e hold that in a rental of any premises for dwelling purposes… there is an implied warranty that the premises are fit for human occupation… This warranty (in so far as it is based on the State Sanitary Code and local health regulations) cannot be waived by any provision in the lease or rental agreement.’ … Under the formula applied by the judge, a rental of defective premises would be tantamount to a waiver of the statutory provisions for enforcement of the State Sanitary Code….”

*Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91 [1982].proposition: The continuing mold condition violates the **State Sanitary Code** (105 C.M.R. 410.602, 410.500, 410.750) and thus constitutes interference with the quiet enjoyment of the premises (*McKenna v. Begin*, 3 Mass. App. Ct. 168 [1975]*; *Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91 [1982]*).
*Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91 [1982].support_reasoning: The opinion expressly ties the landlord’s duty to maintain the premises to compliance with the State Sanitary Code, and then links violation of that duty (the repeated flooding/unsanitary water condition) both to breach of the warranty of habitability and to interference with quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14. While the case’s facts involve flooding/sewage rather than mold by name, the court’s reasoning is that unsanitary, non‑watertight conditions violating the sanitary code constitute interference with quiet enjoyment, which directly supports using sanitary code violations (such as mold conditions) as the basis for such a claim.
*Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91 [1982].relevant_excerpt: “At a minimum, this warranty imposes on the landlord a duty to keep the dwelling in conformity with the State Sanitary Code… There was evidence at trial that the wall between Solomon’s apartment and the adjoining basement area was extremely porous… Further, a section of the State Sanitary Code (received in evidence), provides that apartments must be watertight… The water in Solomon’s apartment was a preventable situation, and one that Gem had a duty to prevent. See 105 Code Mass. Regs. 410.500… Therefore, Gem is liable under G. L. c. 186, § 14.”

*Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas*, 417 Mass. 78.proposition: Plaintiff is entitled to at least **three months’ rent in damages** or **actual damages**, whichever is greater, under **G.L. c. 186, § 14** (*Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas*, 417 Mass. 782 [1994]*; *Reis v. Commissioner of Div. of Unemployment Assistance*, 438 Mass. 777 [2003]*).
*Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas*, 417 Mass. 78.support_reasoning: The opinion directly quotes and applies G.L. c. 186, § 14, stating that a landlord who interferes with quiet enjoyment “shall … be liable for actual and consequential damages or three month’s rent, whichever is greater.” The court further holds that Thomas established a § 14 violation and is at least entitled to attorney’s fees on that basis, thereby affirming that the statutory measure of damages is a minimum of three months’ rent or actual damages, whichever is greater. Thus, the case supports the stated proposition about the damages standard under § 14.
*Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas*, 417 Mass. 78.relevant_excerpt: General Laws c. 186, § 14 (1992 ed.), provides, in pertinent part, that “any lessor or landlord who directly or indirectly interferes with the quiet enjoyment of any residential premises by the occupant . . . shall ... be liable for actual and consequential damages or three month’s rent, whichever is greater, and the costs of the action, including a reasonable attorney’s fee.”

*Reis v. Commissioner of Div. of Unemplo.raw_text: *Reis v. Commissioner of Div. of Unemployment Assistance*, 438 Mass. 777 [2003]
*Reis v. Commissioner of Div. of Unemplo.proposition: Plaintiff is entitled to at least **three months’ rent in damages** or **actual damages**, whichever is greater, under **G.L. c. 186, § 14** (*Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas*, 417 Mass. 782 [1994]*; *Reis v. Commissioner of Div. of Unemployment Assistance*, 438 Mass. 777 [2003]*).
*Reis v. Commissioner of Div. of Unemplo.support_reasoning: This opinion is a criminal case about a murder conviction and related trial-rights issues; it does not involve landlord-tenant law, G.L. c. 186, § 14, rent, or damages. Nothing in the text addresses statutory damages for interference with quiet enjoyment or any civil remedy, so it cannot support the proposition about entitlement to three months’ rent or actual damages under G.L. c. 186, § 14.
*Reis v. Commissioner of Div. of Unemplo.relevant_excerpt:
The defendant also seeks relief pursuant to G. L. c. 278, § 33E. We reject all claims of error. We also discern no basis to grant relief under G. L. c. 278, § 33E. Accordingly, we affirm the defendant’s conviction and the order denying his motion for a new trial.
...
Although we have suggested that a proper charge on murder should comprise a full reading of the murder statute, G. L. c. 265, § 1...
